_header: Our Host saw well that the bright sun
Title(s): Introduction to the Man of Law’s Tale; Canterbury Tales
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the Introduction to the Man of Law’s Tale of the Canterbury Tales — 98 lines in couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
OVre Oste saw wel that the bright sonnethe arke of his artificial
                    day had ronne…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…and with that worde he with a sobre cherebigan his tale as ye
                    shal after here
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
…And nexte / bigynneth the man of lawe his prolog & cetera
                    (f. 141); the man of lawes prolog (RT); Here endith the man of lawe his
                    prolog… (f. 142v)

BodBar20.First Lines:
Owre ost saw wel þat þe bright sonneThe arke of his
                    artificial day hath ronne…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…And with þat word he with a sobes chereBygan his tale as
                    ȝe shal aftir here
BodBar20.Attributed Title:
…and here bygynnyth / þe Prologe of þe man of law (f.
                        62v); The man of law (RT); here endith þe prologe of þe
                    man of law… (f. 64)

Bod414.First Lines:
[O]ure host saugh wel þat þe briȝt sunneThe arche of
                    his artificial day haþ runne…
Bod414.Last Lines:
…And with that wurd he with a sobir chereBegan his tale as ye
                    shulle aftir here

Bod686.First Lines:
Oure host saugh wel þat þe bryght sonneþe ark of his
                    artificial day hath y ronne…
Bod686.Last Lines:
…I speke in prose and let hym rymes makeAnd with þat word
                    he with a sory chereBygan his tale as ye may after here
Bod686.Attributed Title:
Here folowen the wordes of the hoost / vnto the man of lawe (f. 56); Hoost
                    (RT); Here enden the words of the hoost / vnto the man of lawe… (f.
                    57)

BodHatDon1.First Lines:

                    artificiall day hath y ron…
BodHatDon1.Last Lines:
…And with þat worde with a sobre chereBigan his tale as
                    ye shall aftre here
BodHatDon1.Attributed Title:
…And next biginneth þe prolog of þe man of lawes tale (f.
                        50v); The prolog of þe man of lawe (RT)

BodLauMis600.First Lines:
Oure host saugh wel þat þe bright sonneThe ark of his
                    artificial dai haþ ronne…
BodLauMis600.Last Lines:
…And wiþ þat worde he with a sobre
                    chereBegynneþ his tale as ye shul aftir here
BodLauMis600.Attributed Title:
…Here begynneþ þe prolog of þe man of lawe (f.
                        125v); þe man of lawe (RT)

BodLauMis739.First Lines:
[O]Wre oste saugh wele þat the bryghte sonneThe ark of his
                    artificiale day had ronne…
BodLauMis739.Last Lines:
…And with that worde he with a sobre chereBigan his tale as
                    ȝe shall here
BodLauMis739.Note:
The exemplar apparently had two sheets disarranged, as the MS has II.91
                    followed by 173-254 (fols. 82v-83v, with a later
                    corrector’s marks indicating the proper sequence), followed in turn by
                    93-172, 337-418, 255-336, 419, etc. London,  British Library Royal 18 C.II (no. 34 below) has the
                    same sequence of misarranged lines due to transposed folios and thus may be the
                    exemplar for this portion of the Laud MS.

OxfNew314.First Lines:
Oure oste saw þat by þe briȝt sonneThe Ark of his
                    artificial day had ronne…
OxfNew314.Last Lines:
…And with þat word he wit a sobir chereBegan
                    his tale as ye shul here
OxfNew314.Attributed Title:

OxfTri49.First Lines:
oure hoste sawe welle that the bright sonnethe cooke of his
                    artificial day hath ronne…
OxfTri49.Last Lines:
…and with that worde he with a sobre cherebegan his tale as ye
                    shul aftir here
OxfTri49.Note:
II.36 omitted. There is a small ‘h’ guide letter where an
                    ‘o’ might be expected, for which a lombard ‘T’ was
                    executed, but the first word of text is ‘oure’.

CULGg427.First Lines:
…And þerfore by þe schadewe he tok hese witThat
                    phebus which þat schon so cler & bryȝt…
CULGg427.Last Lines:
…Of swiche cursede storyis I seye fyOr ellis of Thiro
                    appolonyus…

BLRoy17Dxv.First Lines:
Ower oste saughe well the brighte sonneThe Arke of his Artificiall
                    daye haþe yronne…
BLRoy17Dxv.Last Lines:
…And with that worde he with A sobre chereBigan his tale as ye
                    schullen after here
BLRoy17Dxv.Attributed Title:
…And / begynnythe the prologe of the Man of Lawe (f. 79v);
                    Here endith the prolog of þe man of lawe… (f. 81)

BLRoy18Cii.First Lines:
OWre ost saugh wel þat þe brighte sonneThe ark of his
                    artificial day hadde ronne…
BLRoy18Cii.Last Lines:
…And with þat word he with a sobre cheereBigan his tale
                    as ye shal after here
BLRoy18Cii.Note:
Two bifolia are transposed (ff. 69+72 and 70+71), producing the sequence
                    II.91 followed by 173-254, 337-418, 255-336, 419, etc. Oxford,  Bodleian Library Laud misc. 739 (SC 1234)
                        (no. 7 above) has
                    the same sequence of misarranged lines. The scribe indicates the correct
                    ordering in a series of notations at the foot of ff. 69, 70v, top of
                    f. 71, bottom of f. 71v, top of f. 72, foot of f. 72v, and
                    top of f. 73.
BLRoy18Cii.Attributed Title:
The prolog of the man of lawe (f. 67v); The man of lawe (RT);
                    Here endyth the prolog… (f. 70)

                    sonne…

PhilRos10841.First Lines:
…That loued hir oune brother synfullyOf such cursed storyes y
                    sey fy…
PhilRos10841.Last Lines:
…And with that worde he with a sobre chereBygan hys tale as ye
                    schl after here
PhilRos10841.Note:
II.1-78 lost. The MS is misbound, with [13].8 following [12].7 (becoming
                    f. 43) and Q [14] misbound to follow Q [12] (with [14] foliated 44-51, and [13]
                    foliated 52-57). Quires [1-4] and [6-7] are inferred to be lost, with the
                    foliation not taking account of them. Thus V.9-91 follow II.558-1190 and are in
                    turn followed by II.79-557; a blank leaf follows, and then V.92, etc. V.656-72
                    lost; 134-40 omitted.

PhilRos10842.Transcription:
…Ther I com aftir him þe wich have be lakeI speke in prose
                    and lete him rymes makeAnd with tho wordis he with a sobir chereBegan
                    his tale as yee shul aftir here

Woodward,  Daniel,  and  Martin Stevens, eds.  
             The New Ellesmere Chaucer Facsimile (Huntington MS EL 26 C 9).
         Tokyo: Yushodo, and San Marino, CA: Huntington Library, 1995: Now available in part online: http://dpg.lib.berkeley.edu/webdb/dsheh/heh_brf?CallNumber=El+26+C+9.
HunEL26C9.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Ellesmere Manuscript of Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales.
Chaucer Society
         Series 1, nos. 2, 8, 16, 26, 32, 38, 50, 70. London: Trübner,
            1868-79.

BNangl39.First Lines:
Oure host saugh that þe bright sonnethe ark of his artificial
                    had ronne…
BNangl39.Last Lines:
…and with that wurd he with a sobre cherebegan his tale as yee
                    shul aftir heere
BNangl39.Attributed Title:
…& subsequen / ter sequntur verba Galfridi Chauncers /
                        compilatoris libri (f. 24va); Verba Hospitis ad totam
                        comitinam (f. 24va); Verba hospitis ad seruientem
                        legis (f. 24vb); Responsio ad hospitem (f.
                        24vb)

TokyoTak24.First Lines:
Oure oost sauȝ that the briȝt sonneThe arke of his
                    artificial day hath ronne…
TokyoTak24.Last Lines:
…And with that word he with a sober chereBegan his tale as ye
                    shal aftir hiere
TokyoTak24.Attributed Title:
…And hiere beginneth / the Prolog of the man of lawe (rubric, f.
                    54)

TokyoTak32.First Lines:
Ovre ost sawe weell that the bryght svnneThe ark of his artificial
                    day hadde I runne…
TokyoTak32.Last Lines:
…and with that word hee with a sobre chereBy gan his tale as
                    yee schll after here
